_prev_prog_3.Description: The facility's Process Safety Management Program evaluates and updates process and mechanical safety procedures and programs in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Plant City Facility is a phosphate fertilizer manufacturing complex that handles anhydrous ammonia, a commercial chemical that is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Its most extensive use is in soil fertilization as a source of nitrogen, which is essential for plant growth. The Plant City Facility maintains an extensive environmental, health and safety program that ensures compliance with all applicable local, state and federal rules and regulations. In fact, the facility operates under a Corporate Policy that endorses going beyond regulatory requirements when prudent to enhance the protection of the health and safety of its employees and the public. The design, maintenance and operation of this facility are carried out in compliance with this program and policy in order to provide safe operations and to prevent exposure of our employees and our neighbors to ammonia.



The Plant City Facility Emergency Response Plan is based upon OSHA's hazardous waste operations and emergency response standard [29 CFR 1910.120(q)]. The plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. Additional response procedures include: Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) trained operating and supervisory personnel, emergency response drills with local emergency responders, ammonia sensors located at critical locations in the process area, continuous monitoring of ammonia sensor readings, continuous recording of weather conditions, and fog nozzles and other equipment for ammonia suppression.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



The Plant City Facility receives shipments of anhydrous ammonia by rail. The ammonia is transferred from the railcars to pressurized ammonia tanks. The ammonia is pumped from the tanks directly to the four granulation plants, where it is combined with phosphoric acid to produce ammonium p

hosphate fertilizers. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



The only substance covered under EPA's RMP regulatory program at this facility is ammonia. 



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The Accidental Release Prevention Program of this facility is the OSHA Process Safety Management Program (PSM) and the EPA Program 3 Prevention Program.  The primary purpose of this facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program is to safeguard our employees and our neighbors from exposure to ammonia by evaluating and updating the facility's process and mechanical safety procedures and programs on a routine basis. This facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program was developed in compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management Rule 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and with EPA's Risk Management Regulation 40 CFR 68.



Chemical-specific prevention steps have been taken by this facility to minimize and mitigate potential releases.  Equipment, instrumentation, procedures, and inspections are in place to enhance the accidental release program.  These include:  Emergency Shutdown system, ammonia detectors, ammonia excess flow valves, video surveillance, ammonia storage inspections, and instrumentation inspections and calibrations.



Five Year Accident History



In the past five years, there has been one ammonia release that met the RMP rule criteria for reporting.  The event resulted in onsite impacts only.



Emergency Response Program



HAZMAT training is performed in accordance with OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.120 (g) and pre-emergency planning and drills have been conducted with outside responders. The emergency response program conforms to the OSHA Process Safety Management Program as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.119. The HAZMAT team has conducted joint training and drills with the local fire departm

ents. Facility personnel have conducted meetings informing the public of the facility's Emergency Response Program. The facility uses the Incident Command System that was developed by the National Fire Academy.



The facility installed alarms and a telephone notification system for the surrounding community in 1999. Those notification measures remain in effect. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



This facility will continue to work with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and emergency responders to plan for all appropriate emergency response through training, practice, and drills and to support emergency response actions in the event of a chemical release.
